title: 113_hr1557
content: The "Plain Regulations Act of 2013" aims to enhance the clarity and effectiveness of Federal agency regulations by promoting clear and easily understandable language for the public to comply with. It defines key terms like "agency," "regulation," and "plain language" to ensure better communication and accountability. SEC. 4. RESPONSIBILITIES OF FEDERAL AGENCIES. Federal agencies must prepare for the implementation of plain writing requirements for regulations by designating senior officials, communicating the requirements to employees, training them to use plain language, establishing compliance oversight processes, and serving as points of contact for public input. Federal agencies must designate persons to implement the Plain Writing Act of 2010 and use plain language in new and revised regulations within 12 months of enactment. Compliance certification is required for all proposed and final regulations. The Plain Writing Act of 2010 requires agencies to certify that proposed or final regulations are in plain language. Agency actions to collect information for regulation clarity are exempt from certain information collection provisions. SEC. 5. RESPONSIBILITIES OF OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET. The Director must return any regulation not following plain language guidance to the agency for redrafting. Certifications from agency heads will be published on the Office of Management and Budget's official website. SEC. 6. REPORTS. SEC. 6. REPORTS. Agencies must publish compliance reports on their websites within specified timeframes. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW AND ENFORCEABILITY. SEC. 7. JUDICIAL REVIEW AND ENFORCEABILITY. No court can review compliance with this Act, and no provision creates enforceable rights through legal action.
